text: Yeah, Gary, thanks for that. And Gaylene, you might be able to remind me as well. In the past, we used to, Council always used to notify Ngāi Wī Tūpua Waipara of any properties that were going up for sale before we actually put them on the market. That was correct, wasn't it?
speaker: jimmylchreest

text: Yep, that's right.
speaker: gayleneroberts

text: Yeah, so I suppose from Council's perspective at the moment, where the properties are not derived from the Crown, where there is a first right of refusal, that  The feeling is that for us to get the best return for our properties, they need to follow our policy for putting them on the open market and getting the best deal that we can for the ratepayers. So it's felt that that first right of refusal can actually inhibit that, but we've got no objection to actually  keeping everybody informed on what properties that we are or have identified for sale. And there's no urgency in terms of selling properties. We've always got plenty of time. That's not always the case when we're actually purchasing properties where we've sometimes got to make a quick decision on a purchase to fit in with the vendor's timeline.  So, look, it's not that we don't want to keep everybody informed, but it's just a matter of just making sure that our policy is fair to everyone. So, look, it's still got to go through that formal process, but that's probably where the Council is sitting at the moment. But, Gaylene, I'm just wondering whether reinstigating that  form a practice of notifying you of actual properties that were coming up for sale, whether that would be a good idea. Have you got any ideas on that?

text: So, look, just before we get on to questions, in terms of the Three Waters reform, whilst the central government have mandated the  changes to four water entities across the country. A number of councils and Waipā included in that are, I was going to say, resisting those changes. We all acknowledge that, you know,  there is a need to make sure that we've got safe drinking water throughout the country and a higher standard of waste discharges to make sure that our waterways are not polluted. But there is a real concern about a four waters entity, 22 councils for Entity B, which is what Waipā would be part of. And  effectively the transfer of assets to the new water entities with no recognition or compensation for the investment that the ratepayers have made for many decades and building up those assets. But it's more the management and governance, I suppose, of those water entities,  the proposal is that the boards or the new entities are controlled by six local authority members and six iwi members. And there is concern about how much control councils like Waipā would have being  potentially not having anyone influencing the direction of those new water entities. And I had a, I suppose it was an informal meeting with Hamilton City, Waikato, and Linda from Waikato Tainui, and Linda Te Aho's concern was very similar to, I think, local government is how  Can anybody have any influence over such a big organisation? And in fact, from Tainui's perspective, it was  I suppose the scale of the entity was too large and they weren't supportive of the new entities. So, across the country now, there is quite a lot of resistance building from local government. Initially, the  option of opting out or opting into the proposal was there, but that was taken away at the last minute. There was no chance for councils to talk to their communities about it. So, at the moment, there's 17 councils that have signed up to  go back to central government and say, hey, we understand that there's a need to improve water supplies and discharges by stormwater and sewage across the country. But we don't believe that the model that you put forward is acceptable to our community.  and or communities. And I suspect that there'll be more councils that actually join that grouping to try to negotiate with central government to actually pause and to look at a system that would work for us going forward. So although it's been mandated, the bill hasn't still been passed and  there is an opportunity, I hope, to actually negotiate a more realistic option for WIPA. And I suppose, and I stated at a meeting earlier, might have even been just yesterday, that my position all the way through has been that if the,  changes would be in the best interests of Waipā ratepayers, who are our electors, then I'd be for it. But I'm still not convinced that it will provide a better service for Waipā or at a cheaper price. So, look, I'm fully supportive of the pushback that's coming from local government. But I'd certainly be interested in any comments that you have  No. Were there any other questions in on that report of Martin's? Okay. Nothing. So can I have a mover and seconder for the recommendation to receive the report? I'm happy to move, Jim. Susan and Andrew. All those in favour?  Aye. Contrary, carried. District Plan Work Program, item eight. Who's handling that for us?
speaker: jimmylchreest

text: I would like to take the report as read and just talk to a couple of matters. The first one being, as you may be aware, that the government released its Resource Management and Abling Housing Support and Other Matters Amendment Bill. So, I'm just going to go through a couple of things.  This has already been discussed with the Strategic Planning and Policy Committee. A submission was drafted and we did present to the select committee. So basically the bill will amend the Resource Management Act and will allow in places for up to three three-story houses to be built in what is classified as urban areas.  So there'll be no need for resource consents as long as you meet certain standards. The government is calling this a medium density residential standard. So if the bill is passed, we will have to basically do a plan change to the district plan. And then we will have to  and notify at the latest by the 20th of August next year for those changes to occur. Currently, we were working on a draft plan change 21 to give effect to the urban density standard set out in the national policy statement. So potentially we could do what's required under this resource management bill  in conjunction with Plan Change 21, it's a very different concept and it's designed to accelerate, hopefully, the provision of housing and potentially more affordable housing. Whether it's successful remains to be seen.  And basically it's a watch the space over the next six to eight months to see what comes out.  What else? The other thing is the select committee reported back on the new RMA, the Natural and Built Environments Act bill. Essentially, a lot of work needs to be done on the bill. A lot of work needs to be done to incorporate the concept of te oranga o te taiao.  into the bill further. It's got to be included now into the purpose of that Act. There's further work to be carried out with national iwi and Māori groups to further develop the concept. They want the effectiveness of Te Auranga o Te Taiau heightened by trying to define it and describing how  the new resource management legislation will support the upholding of the concept. The bill is also now required to state that in addition to the relationships that iwi and Māori have with Te Taio, it needs to be made clear that all New Zealanders have relationships with and responsibilities to look after the natural environment.  and consideration needs to be given to mana o te wai haeraki which has been introduced in another national policy statement for fresh water and how that haeraki can be incorporated to be placed within the purpose clause of the new act. So a lot more work  to be done. The select committee wants a lot more opportunities made available to iwi and Māori to participate more effectively and comprehensively under this piece of legislation. They want the national planning framework to be able to  support the principles of Te Tiriti o Waitangi and they want those principles now to be given effect to as well. So yeah, a lot of work needs to be done. They're still aiming to have all  three of the acts in some form by the end of 2022. And definitely, it'll be a watchless space in the next 12 months, and we'll be reporting back accordingly. Any questions?
speaker: jocookmunrose

text: Thanks, Jo. Were there any questions that the committee had? Yeah, Gaylene.
speaker: jimmylchreest

text: Yeah, and ain't that gonna be a headache?
speaker: gayleneroberts

text: Yeah, sure is.  Yeah, Gaylene, I suppose, well, to everybody really, Council is not opposed to intensification of housing as long as it's well thought out and planned and the infrastructure, not only the pipes and the roads and everything,  are properly designed, but it's also the playgrounds, the parks and reserves and those things that are not likely to be.  I suppose, if people start just building additional houses on sections now and what impact that's going to have on the neighbourhood. So, we think there'll be a whole lot of perverse implications on what's being proposed by central government.  And I think everybody agrees that we need to get more housing for people. That's absolutely the case. But just to have a knee-jerk reaction and propose that you can build three three-storey houses on existing sections and not have an adverse impact on the social standing of those areas is a bit of a shame.  is crazy, really. So, we're pushing back in terms of the proposal, but obviously making provisions in our own district plan to enable higher density. But the proposition that there's going to be no car parking required and all of those sorts of things having to take place out on the street is not going to be a sensible proposition. So,  Yeah, it was interesting that local government wasn't consulted on this before it went forward, and yet both National and Labour are supporting the change. So whether we're successful in our submission to the select committee or not, I don't know. But it's certainly  going to cause a great deal of concern for a lot of our existing residents and ratepayers. If you start getting big houses, well, tall houses, not necessarily big, built on the, pretty much on the boundary, it's only a one metre setback. The overshadowing, the loss of views, all of those things are going to cause a significant issue for  for existing residents. So, yeah, as you said, Gaylene, isn't that going to be fun trying to control that? But that's where we're sitting at the minute.
speaker: jimmylchreest

text: Yeah, the concern is, is they've only kind of dealt with one part of the issue, which is the provision of housing.  I'm fortunate enough that I have stepchildren who live in the UK, and they're in a very intensified area, but they're also within 500 meters of a massive park with their green spaces, and they also have, they get parking permits for being residents. And this bill, it doesn't address the need that we all have as humans that we want green space, and we want to be able to walk somewhere,  or, you know, playing in a park. And this doesn't, this bill doesn't require that in conjunction with the intensification. And you could end up with the old housing projects that they used to have in London, where it was just concrete block buildings and no outside area. And I mean, we're all human, and especially with lockdown and the traffic light system continuing, we all have a need to be able to go outside and enjoy the outdoors.  you know, even if you just stand in your driveway and breathe in the air and stand in the sun. So, yeah, there's definitely concern there because it's not a coordinated approach across the board for what you need with housing.
speaker: jocookmunrose

text: So historical urban values that we could lose too in projects like this.  people have got used to living in the historical way. Yeah, so these developments tend to, could shift that. And I'm not completely sure everybody's gonna agree with that either.
speaker: gayleneroberts

text: I think you're right, Gaylene. There is a demand for the traditional quarter acre section for one of the description, but there are a lot of people now looking for higher density, which is fine. If you're a young couple or an elderly couple that don't want to be looking after gardens anymore, but they still need access to the open spaces.  So, we've got to make provision for it, and especially along main transport corridors and things like that, where there's good public transport. But to mess up what's already there traditionally is not a sensible approach, in my opinion, that's for sure. Welcome, Hazel. I saw you sneak in there.  Okay, were there any other comments on?

But council also will need to upskill and designate certain people. I mean, at the moment, you have Gary and Shane who do such a wide variety. text: Okay, the refresher of the economic wellbeing strategy is underway. This is a verbal update on the process and an opportunity to import into the early development of the strategy. We've formed a business advisory group to provide some sector input and there will be workshop opportunities for members and councillors.  The current strategy was adopted way back 2012, prepared in consultation with partners, stakeholders and sector representatives. And we will use this approach again, seeking some expert opinion on the way. The strategy will be workshopped with elected members in the new year and brought to Council for approval at the May 2020 meeting.  A working vision for the strategy, which we might like to discuss, is a plan to create a diverse, resilient, and sustainable economy that serves the needs of our current and future community, to identify key economic issues and risks going forward. And there's plenty of those. And the strategy will support activity that promotes the vision above.  and while also supporting community outcomes based on the four well-beings. And to support the White Pass Vision community outcomes, external priorities, and you've seen those coming through the other strategy development that's in progress. So the economic well-being is an economically progressive part of the economic well-beings.  integrates with creating vibrant communities and leading the recovery of Waipā. There's a number of strategies that you have seen or are coming that support our vision and community outcomes. And in the circle box at the bottom, environmental strategy, transport strategy, Waipā 2050 growth and the economic wellbeing strategy.  We have moved a little bit to economic, well, we have moved to economic wellbeing from economic development. Economic development is predicated on growth and GDP growth, but there are other things going on in our economy and our community, and we need to take account of those. So what's changed since 2012?  We've been recognised by High Growth District, Tier 1, the inclusion and re-inclusion of the four well-beings in the Local Government Act, and Council's intention to be a strategy leader organisation. So a global panic pandemic has created uncertainties around the future structure of the economy. It's changed the way we live our lives. And a new government with high ambitions for change  is moving at pace. It's an acceptance of climate change and sustainability as fundamental issues for policy direction and action. And this strategy will integrate with those other strategies that also will be coming before you. And there's a strong sentiment to grow the economy and community in a way that's more diverse and resilient.  I grow back better. So the original strategy had their seven key theme areas, business growth and attraction, tourism, high performance sport, information technology, sustainable agriculture, agrotech.  aviation, education, youth employment. So these may come across to the new strategy. They may be supplemented or augmented, and there may well be new action plans around those seven original outcome areas. So the strategy is council-led with sector input from a business advisory group.  and the overall strategy be considered by key partners, stakeholders and elected members. The business advisory group will include Maori business owners, business facing organisations, chamber of commerce, high site and business and local business sector groups, including tourism, high performance sport, technical  technology and agriculture. These have been important group sectors in our economy. Mana Whenua, Tiwaka and Hamilton Waikato Tourism. These groups sometimes have their own produce plans, which will inform the development of the strategy. And we'll be looking at ways for those groups to  to contribute and provide input and direct our strategy development. Next steps of the strategy, intended to have a couple of business advisory group meetings also with elected members. And the purpose of these is to provide external support, external and sector input.  Early ideas will be brought back to council by the end of the year, possibly in the Friday update. And then discussions with wider stakeholder groups in February, March next year. Some verbal updates next year and strategy presented for adoption in the May council meeting.  So, any questions now and discussion? Those are the wellbeing measures from the wellbeing budget in the treasury framework. And that's largely what council is following along with our own vision and strategy. So, if I can stop sharing my screen now.  be really interested in some wider discussion. Any comments anyone?

speaker: jimmylchreest

text: Just one moment. Okay, thank you. Thank you very much for the opportunity to speak to you about the transport strategy. We're now really pleased to have a draft strategy and a short presentation to share outlining the transport strategy for discussion and feedback today.  I have to apologize to the Ngā Iwi Tupu representatives at the meeting last week as I wasn't quite able to finish the presentation due to internet problems. So hopefully we'll be able to complete it all today.  So the draft strategy is an update from the 2010 strategy in line with current policy, growth and community outcomes, provides a long-term view for transport projects through identifying transport issues and areas for focus, objectives and actions for the future. The strategy also considers how we might actually move around in the future with technology changes, transport modes changing, et cetera, et cetera.  electric vehicles coming on board, those sort of things. So the project phases, there were five key phases to this project. The project kicked off with a review of the previous strategy that was developed in 2010, which showed a number of completed transport projects such as the  the new Cambridge section of the Waikato Expressway, Te Awa Cycleway from Lake Kawerau to the Avanti Drome, Cambridge and Poronga Town Concept Plans, a new Regional Passenger Transport Plan, and a number of safety improvements, speed limits around schools, speed limit bylaw, and more cycleways such as the newly opened or newly developed Hamilton Road Cycleway.  Through the information gathering phase, we reviewed a number of policies and strategies that I'll talk to you about on the next slide. We also pulled together crash data, census data, household and employment data, and we ran the Waikato Regional Transport Model to understand what the traffic might look like in the future.  We had two workshops with stakeholders and attended Ngā Iwi Tupu Hui in April, May, July, and recently in November last week.  Workshops were also held with the elected members of the council for the transport strategy. This is a slide of the policies that we have to consider for the transport strategy. Things have changed in the last few years, and there's been more of a focus on providing more transport options and our response to climate change. And that's been led by things like the government policy statement on land transport,  I probably won't read through all of those national documents, but importantly, probably the most important one is the government policy statement. Because our transport projects have to align with that strategy and the priorities of safety  road safety, better travel options, improving freight connections and climate change. Regionally, we have the Waikato Regional Land Transport Plan, that's the RLTP, and our transport strategy has to align with that document. That's about the regional priorities for funding for transport projects.  At our district level, the strategy aligns with the council's community outcomes, such as creating vibrant communities and preparing for climate change. Two key priorities where the transport strategy can help with. The transport strategy will also help to inform the council's community spatial plan and that work is currently underway.  This is the strategy structure that we followed. We developed a vision. We had focus areas that were pulled together from talking with iwi and stakeholders. We identified objectives and outcomes, and we prepared some high level actions.  This is the vision. It has been proposed. The vision was workshop with iwi and stakeholders and elected representatives. And we came up with the words, people in freight and Waipā have access to an integrated, safe, sustainable transport system that provides a range of travel choices.  We're also very grateful for the whakatauki provided by Ngā Iwi Taupō representatives. I ha te me nui o te ao. E tangata, e tangata, e tangata. People are at the centre of our solutions, highlighting the need to understand where people in Waipā travel and their differing transport needs, and working in partnership for the transport strategy outcomes.  Feedback, we're also really grateful to iwi representatives through the hui for feedback on issues that are important for us to consider for the transport strategy. Those include things such as heavy traffic and trucks going past Kihikihi School and the possible need for the future, a need for a bypass through Kihikihi.  Speed around schools and marae, particularly, obviously, rurally as well. Lack of licence appointments for new driving licences.  to actually get appointments, to actually kick off the process to get your driver's license. Concerns around rural areas in terms of safety and access. Incorporating e-bikes, mobility scooters, etc. into planning. Mobility parks taken up by able-bodied people.  That was actually raised also through the CCS disability people as well. Obviously very important to have those free for people with disabilities. Lack of bus services between Te Aumutu, Cambridge  and particularly destinations such as the Waikato Hospital and the University of Waikato as well. Possible future train connections linking Te Awamutu, Cambridge, Hamilton and regionally, and trucks down the main street and safety concerns. So those particular issues were pulled together into key issues and we came up with five key outcome areas.  Number one, responding to climate change. Number two, supporting growth, economic development and regional connections. Three, making our roads safer for all users. Four, access and mobility. And five, embracing technology. So we just talk briefly about our priority action areas.  Responding to climate change, that's a big thing for transport in terms of reducing our transport emissions and working towards zero carbon emissions to 2050. And that's in terms of focusing on emissions reduction plan and taking steps to ensure transportation targets are met.  We can do this by reducing greenhouse gases, reducing travel, more electric vehicles going around our district, prioritising walking, cycling and public transport to encourage mode shift to reduce transport emissions.  And another big thing is to ensure we continue to monitor the network to ensure its resilience to natural hazards and extreme weather events and ensure those key routes to our communities are kept well managed in terms of if there were natural hazards and extreme weather events.  Next one is about supporting growth, economic development and regional connections. And that's using a tool called the One Network Framework to prioritise how we move around the district, how we prioritise our freight routes, how we prioritise routes for cycling, people spaces over private vehicles, those sort of things.  Continue with our integrated planning, promoting higher and mixed use densities and multimodal transport options. The multimodal means things like including walking, cycling, buses, other ways to get around our district and our towns.  Continuing to work regionally through the Regional Land Transport Programme, FutureProof, the Hamilton Metro Spatial Plan and road safety work, which we do a lot of work with other partners across the region.  Progressing with the Te Aumutu Western Arterials project and that's to look to review the designation for the Western Arterial and look at how we can actually improve other outcomes for Te Aumutu as well.  And finally, the Cambridge Transport Network and safety improvements. Looking at our traffic in Cambridge, looking at our routes across the Waikato River, our bridges, and how we can make future improvements for the future.  Road safety continues to be a big issue in the district, in the region and also nationally. So we would be looking at continuing to roll out the Road to Zero vision. And it's quite a  a strong vision in terms of a New Zealand where no one is killed or seriously injured in road crashes. And that's a focus, a continued focus on safe roads for all users, including pedestrians and cyclists, safe speeds through engineering for lower speeds, continuing to look at our speed limits, looking at improvements around schools, rural schools, marae, etc.  in terms of safety improvements there. Rolling out our safe urban mobility networks, that's our separated paths away from traffic. And there's a whole programme being completed, particularly focus on our bigger towns of Cambridge and Te Awamutu to roll out those networks.  ensuring we provide high quality bus stop facilities to improve safety and security, making sure there's good surveillance, good facilities for people to encourage people to use buses in our district and regionally, and our continued focus on community road safety programmes.  access to mobility. This is my son on the Hamilton Road Cycleway embracing the recreational biking revolution. There's a lot more. We know there's a lot more people recreationally biking. Our challenge is to try and encourage people to  to bike more to workplaces and schools, and we can do that through our urban mobility networks in terms of providing safe facilities for them to get to those destinations and providing facilities there for making sure we can get their bikes locked safely and etc, etc.  The need to grow public transport patronage, and that's through the regional passenger transport work, but also the Hamilton Metro Spatial Plan work, which is looking at improving connections between Te Aumutu and Hamilton and Cambridge and Hamilton in terms of making faster connections. We can also encourage local buses to support those connections as well.  And also exploring rural transport options and enhanced services for transport disadvantaged people. That's things like total mobility services, services for people with disabilities, etc.  Now last area of objectives, embracing technology. This is, as we know, transport is changing and we are starting to see electric vehicles. We'll start to see changes to supporting technology to help  and assist people into public transport or mixed ways of travelling in the future. This diagram just shows examples of how people might travel in the future for short distances. People might, if they're able to, use bikes and scooters. This is particularly in our town areas.  There might be ways that we can just dial up and use local on-demand services, sort of Uber-style networks to travel further distances. And we might also investigate car-sharing schemes that we could use to do regional and longer trips, particularly in the weekends and things. So those are just sort of examples of those.  How we implement the strategy. We've got a whole lot of indicators there that we can keep track of the strategy. There's a whole lot of acronyms in this next stop point, but basically there's a whole lot of regional projects and district wide projects where we can incorporate and  implement project actions through these. Such things as also working within the community spatial plan in the district, the asset management plan in the district plan are key ways that we can influence and put our actions into the transport strategy.  Also through encouraging good design and measures to encourage mode shift. And that's looking at our parking, our parking management, other things that we can do, enhancing travel and encouraging travel behavior programs as well. So our next steps, we've completed the draft strategy, which we'll have a copy  Within the agenda, we're in the engagement side of things. We are looking at early next year, subject to endorsement at council, next week of going out to public consultation early in the new year with the adoption of the strategy soon after that.

text: Thank you, Your Worship. Just with regard to the report that you have on your agenda, I'd like to ask that that be taken as read. It has focused on matters that may be of interest to mana whenua and iwi. So I'll just speak to those very briefly.  With regard to this work stream, which is a key part of phase two of this project, which will take us from September through until October 2022, we have a mana whenua iwi work stream. We have developed an engagement plan, and we also have engaged Stephen Wilson as an external advisor to guide us in terms of how we  effectively engage with mana whenua and iwi. So we've had the first round of hui focused on providing an introduction and overview as to what the Waipa Community Spatial Plan is and what we're hoping it will achieve. Talking about working in partnership with mana whenua and iwi  providing discussion on membership to the PCG. So we had members that were appointed on an interim basis, and I'll come back to that, and then looking at gaps.  Coming out of the three hui, there was a lot of really valuable feedback. So we've taken that away. And one of the things that we looked at was how we capture Māori aspirations within this plan.  had an introduction to an interactive GIS tool. So we have followed that up and we have a dedicated wānanga which is scheduled to be held this Friday, the 3rd of December. And the purpose of that will be to further explore those suggestions, areas where mana whenua and iwi might like to share information with us and see that captured  There was some conversation about how we protect information that is shared, and we have developed up a statement that will be provided to attendees prior to that wānanga on Friday. We're hoping that we'll be able to get that out later today. With regards to the PCG, so that comprises  elected member representation, Mayor Jim, Deputy Mayor Liz and Susan O'Regan as chairperson of the Strategic Planning and Policy Committee sit on that PCG. And we've previously discussed with you mana whenua iwi representation, so feedback from this committee and Iwi Topo Waipa  On that basis, Gaylene, Portal, and Bill were put onto the PCG as interim members. That was discussed through the hui, and a further suggestion was made that Harold Maniapoto and his nominee, Alternate, be put forward to be members of that PCG.  So there is a PCG meeting later today, and that is one of the recommendations that will be considered and determined. With regard to the role of the PCG, it's to provide approval as to project milestones and deliverables. It's to act as a sounding board and to provide guidance.  It's to provide feedback on engagement material and also to make recommendations to elected members who are the ultimate decision maker with regard to the development of this plan. So happy to respond to any questions that you may have, but otherwise possibly just leave it there.

So today I'm going to give you a brief update on our plans to harvest part of the Porongia forest and some of the consultation we're planning for the replanting in 2023. So I'll just share my screen. Okay, is that up? No.  OK, yeah, we are getting there. Getting there now. OK, so just so you got the put on your forest harvest presentation up there. Yeah, OK, excellent, thank you.

speaker: jimmylchreest

text: OK, so just by way of background, so Council owns 284 hectares of forest land in Porongia. It's currently in two blocks, one off Sainsbury Road and the other off Te Tahi Roads. So we are planning to harvest approximately 43 hectares of the Sainsbury Road block. Just put up the plan attached there. So in pink, circled in pink, is around about 35 hectares.  And the piece in blue is around about eight hectares. So the line up here is Sainsbury Road. We take off onto the forestry tracks. So there's basically two blocks on Sainsbury Road we're planning to harvest. So once the harvest is complete, we're going to be left with a decision about what the land should be replanted with. And we've got a range of options there from radiata pine to mixed natives and a whole heap of other types of species in between.  The replanting will be undertaken in the winter of 2023. And one of the things that we would like some help with is a decision about replanting. And we're going to do that in consultation with the Parongia community, iwi and other community stakeholders. So in terms of the consultation process, we're planning to do this April to June.  2022. And the main purpose of that consultation is to involve the Porongia community, iwi and other key stakeholders in decision making around the replanting of the forest. And the key objectives are to engage with stakeholders, resident groups, the wider Porongia community and iwi to make sure they're informed with and engaged in the consultation process.  And so that we can, as council, there's a clear direction from the Prongo community, iwi and other key stakeholders on the replanting of the forest for council to consider. And that's really just sort of a brief overview of what we're planning in terms of the consultation. Are there any questions?

text: Yeah, so there's a whole range of options in there in terms of what we would plant with, and it could be mixed natives, for example. There's manuka, and there's kind of a whole, you know, Douglas fir, cypress. So there's a whole range of species. Douglas fir, for example, you know, is another sort of production forest, but things like mixed natives have a very long-term view to them.

text: Yeah, okay.  So there are any comments at the moment, but there will be that consultation round starting next April.

text: Yep. Potentially, that's something that could be considered as well. Yeah. So all of those sorts of things are sort of what we need. text: Just on Carl's behalf, just a quick update. This is pretty much a standing item now until we get it resolved. So with COVID, you'll remember we were kind of attacking this two different ways. First of all, there were discussions with DOC around potentially  Running the Council Reserve under DOC rules essentially. So those, with COVID, those conversations seem to have slowed down with DOC and we haven't really heard anything back from them at this stage.  Also aware that Ngāti Unu haven't heard anything back from them as well, so at the moment that that tranche has kind of stalled. We've also lost Ana McElroy and Tauwhike as well, so we're a bit short in the reserves planning area.  On the other side of it though, Cale's team is progressing with capturing all the proposed, well, basically looking at the dog policy across the district. They're capturing all the different changes that are required across the district. And there are a number of them. And they think they're going to be bringing that back to council for a workshop early in the new year. So you can start to see some progress on the policy anyway, in the new year.
